column4: Hey, I'm installing vmware-player and apparently the network configuration decided to kill itself. It returns an error code of 1 and I can't uninstall it via apt-get. How do I force removal of the package?
(apt-get -f remove does nothing.)
dpkg --purge packagename
Ah, crap. I forgot about that! Thank you. :)
Hmm...Trying to remove it, but it refuses to remove--"pre-removal script returned error exit status 1".
it may have its own unstall script you might want to try first.  don't remember for sure.
Yeah, if you install the player independently there is one...not sure whether it's even THERE though.
vmware-install.pl -> bin/vmware-uninstall.pl
try locate vmware-install.pl
Negatory.

hmm dunno.  if you haven't tried a gui package manager, do that. otherwise you'll probably have to search for other people having similar trouble.  ive used vmware numerous times without issue.  wish i could help you more.
I've used it without trouble myself...now I'm confused. :(
anything unusual in /etc/networking/interfaces ?

i suspect as a way to "just get it working"  you could delete /etc/init.d/vmware  and any symlinks in the rc directory start up scripts, then reboot.  that should get it out of your hair for sure.. although leave the half borked install still in place.
It's the package that's the problem.
I can't install anything else due to it.
try this..  dpkg --force --purge packagename

did you try dpkg --force-depends --purge package
